metadata.title: Sonochemical synthesis and physical properties of Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 nano-spinel ferrites

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ultrasonics - Sonochemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ultson
Sonochemical synthesis and physical properties of Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 nano-spinel ferrites
M.A. Almessierea,b, Y. Slimania,⁎, S. Gunerc, M. Sertkold, A. Demir Korkmaze, Sagar E. Shirsathf, A. Baykalg
a Department of Biophysics, Institute for Research and Medical Consultations (IRMC), Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, P.O. Box 1982, 31441 Dammam, Saudi Arabia bDepartment of Physics, College of Science, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, P.O. Box 1982, 31441 Dammam, Saudi Arabia c Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, RWTH Aachen University, D-52074 Aachen, Germany dDeanship of Preparatory Year, Building 450, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, P.O. Box 1982, 31441 Dammam, Saudi Arabia e Department of Chemistry, Istanbul Medeniyet University, 34700 Istanbul, Uskudar, Turkey f School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of New South Wales, Kensington, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia g Department of Nanomedicine Research, Institute for Research and Medical Consultations (IRMC), Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, P.O. Box 1982, 31441 Dammam, Saudi Arabia
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Spinel ferrites Nanoparticles Sonochemical approach Structure Cation distribution Magnetic properties
A B S T R A C T
Nanoparticles (NPs) of composition Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4, where 0.00≤ x≤ 0.10 (hereafter called CNMEuF) were synthesized by sonochemical approach using UZ SONOPULS HD 2070 ultrasonic homogenizer (frequency of 20 kHz and power of 70W). As-synthesized samples were characterized thoroughly to determine the effects of europium ions (Eu3+) substitution on their structure, morphology and magnetic traits. Structural analyses of the synthesized NPs confirmed their high purity and crystalline cubic phases. Percent diffuse reflectance (%DR) data and Kubelka-Munk theory were exploited to evaluate the optical band gap energies of the studied CNMEuF NPs. Values of optical band gap energies obtained from the Tauc plots were observed in the range of 1.47–1.58 eV. The hysteresis loops (at room temperature and 10 K) of synthesized NPs were analyzed to determine their magnetic properties. These NPs disclosed superparamagnetic and hard ferrimagnetic character at room temperature and 10 K, respectively. With exception, the sample with x= 0.10 revealed soft ferrimagnetic behavior at 10 K. Eu3+ doping was shown to have significant influence on the structure and magnetic attributes of the proposed CNMEuF NPs. Values of various magnetic parameters of proposed compositions were reduced with the increase in Eu3+ dopant contents.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, both undoped and doped nano-sized spinel ferrites received great attentions owing to their unique intrinsic electrical and magnetic traits [1,2]. These materials have been employed in numerous fields, such as environment, foods, energy, etc [3–10]. They are utilized in several technological applications including microwave (MW) devices, biotechnology, high-speed digital recording, catalysis, ferrofluids, magnetic disks for recording and refrigeration [11–15]. Additionally, spinel ferrites doped with transition metal or rare earth (RE) elements have been applied for enhanced memory storage, magnetic fluids, high-density magnetic recording and catalysts [16–18]. Over the years, it has been realized that the Co-Ni-Mn systems are also an important material like spinel ferrites. In fact, the low power loss and high
magnetization of Co-Ni-Mn spinels at high frequency make them suitable for diverse applications, thereby considered as potential as spinel ferrites [19]. However, the magnetic and dielectric characteristics of Co-Ni-Mn spinels are decided by their compositions as well as the distribution of cations among the tetrahedral (Td) and octahedral (Oh) lattice sites in the crystallographic unit cell structures [19].
With the advent of nanoscience and nanotechnology, it has been realized that the chemical and physical properties of achieved nanomaterials majorly depend on the used preparation techniques [20,21]. In fact, the quantum confinement effects of the produced nanoparticles (NPs) are governed by the overall morphology (size, shape, geometric dimension, and surface states) [22–24]. The key in the nanomaterials synthesis is the assembly process of the inorganic building block that allows the construction of tailored nanoparticles with desired
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ultsonch.2019.104654 Received 20 May 2019; Received in revised form 17 June 2019; Accepted 21 June 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: yaslimani@iau.edu.sa, slimaniyassine18@gmail.com (Y. Slimani).
Ultrasonics - Sonochemistry 58 (2019) 104654
Available online 22 June 2019 1350-4177/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
properties based on their interatomic spacing and structure [16,25]. Recent studies revealed that the overall attributes of nano-sized
spinel ferrites can be improved by adjusting the nature of RE dopant and its contents [26]. The mechanism of spin coupling between the 3d shell electrons of the magnetic ions and 4f shell electrons of the RE ions was discerned to influence the ordering of magnetic moments. Consequently, the magnetic characteristics of spinel nanoferrites are modified [27]. Generally, the RE ions preferentially occupy the B sites in the spinel structure [28–30]. Therefore, the substitution of the Fe3+ by the trivalent RE ions results in a proposed spinel nanoferrite could cause considerable reduction in the magnetization response [28]. Despite some studies on the magneto-electrical properties of RE ions substituted spinel nanoferrites the established knowledge on Co-Ni-Mn-Fe NPs doped with europium (Eu) ions (referred as CNMEuF NPs) have been deficient.
In this perspective, we report the synthesis and characterizations of some CNMEuF NPs of composition Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 (0.00≤ x≤ 0.10). Sonochemical reaction technique was used to prepare these NPs [31–34]. The impact of varied Eu3+ contents on the structural, morphological, and magnetic characteristics of the proposed CNMEuF NPs was examined. A correlation between the Eu3+ doping mediated modification in the structural and magnetic traits have been established. The proposed compositions were shown to be useful for varieties of advanced devices’ applications.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemical reagents
sections.text: Analytical grade high purity (Merck) Iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate [(Fe(NO3)3·9H2O], Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2·6H2O], Manganese (II) nitrate tetrahydrate [Mn(NO3)3·4H2O], Nickel nitrate [Ni(NO3)2] and Europium oxide (Eu2O3) were utilized as starting materials (without additional purification) to prepare CNMEuF NPs.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization tools
sections.text: The Rigaku Benchtop Miniflex X-ray diffractometer operated with Cu-Kα line was used for the structural investigation. A FEI Titan scanning electron microscope (SEM) attached to energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer was used to image the samples morphology and the elemental compositions, respectively. A FEI Morgagni 268 transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to record the NPs size and distribution. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of NPs in the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1 were obtained by a Bruker FTIR Spectrophotometer. UV–visible diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra of assynthesized CNMEuF NPs in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm were measured via DR spectrophotometer (JASCO V-750). A vibratingsample magnetometer (VSM, Quantum Design SQUID) was employed for magnetic measurements.

sections.heading: 2.3. Sample preparation
sections.text:
Spinel nanoferrites of chemical composition Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 with 0.00≤ x≤ 0.10 were prepared by the sonochemical reaction technique. First, the specific amounts of metal nitrates (batch composition of constituents) were thoroughly mixed in deionized (DI) water of volume 50ml. Second, a definite quantity of Eu2O3 was dissolved in 14ml of concentrated HCl. Later, these two solutions were mixed to each other and added with NaOH solution (2M) to achieve a resultant pH of 11. Finally, the solution was exposed to ultrasonic waves (Ultrasonic Homogenizer UZ SONOPULS HD 2070) of frequency 20 kHz (power of 70W) for 1 h. At the end of ultra-sonication process, the solution temperature was as high as 90 °C because of several collisions. Upon cooling, a fine powder was obtained which was further washed using DI water. Finally, the blackish powder was
isolated from DI water via an external magnet and dried up at 90 °C for 8 h without any calcinations process. As-prepared samples were characterized at room temperature (RT=300 K). Magnetic measurements of all Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 samples were carried out both at RT and at low temperature (T= 10 K) to determine the values of saturation magnetization (Ms), remanence (Mr), squareness ratio (SQR=Mr/Ms), magnetic moment (nB), and coercive field or coercivity (Hc).

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD patterns and cation distribution
sections.text:
Fig. 1 presents the XRD powder patterns of all synthesized
Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 NPs, which consisted of short crystalline peaks corresponding to the diffraction from (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (4 0 0), (4 2 2), (5 1 1) and (4 4 0) lattice planes. Existence of such peaks indicated the pure single phase of synthesized spinel nanoferrites without any external phase. Moreover, the (3 1 1) peak of CNMEuF NPs was shifted towards higher diffraction angles with the increase the Eu3+ contents (Fig. 2). The broadening in XRD peaks clearly signified the shrinkage in the nanocrystallite sizes [35–37]. Table 1 enlists the structural parameters of CNMEuF NPs which were estimated using Rietveld refinement interfaced with Full-proof software. The value of
lattice parameter (a) was shortened with the raise in Eu contents [38,39]. The observed relative shrinkage in the lattice parameter compared to the undoped spinel nanoferrites was attributed to the replacement of some Fe3+ by Eu3+ in the preferred lattice sites [40,41]. The crystallite size estimated using Debye-Scherrer equation was occurred in the range of 12–21 nm.
XRD patterns of prepared CNMEuF NPs were analyzed using Bertaut method [42] to determine the cation occupancy (Table 1). In this method, the ratios of XRD peak intensities such as I220/I440 and I422/I400 for all compositions was evaluated to find the occupancy of cations
Table 1 Europium content dependent variation in the refined structural parameters and cations distribution of as-prepared Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 NPs at RT.
x a (Å) V (Å)3 DXRD ± 0.05 (nm) χ2 RBragg A-site (Tetrahedral) B-site (Octahedral)

Fig. 3. FESEM images of the studied spinel nanoferrites.
(M2+ and M3+) distribution in the preferential lattice sites (Oh and Td) [43]. Results in Table 1 disclosed the linear dependence of cations distribution on the Eu3+ doping contents. Generally, Mn3+ known to occupy 80% of the Td sites and 20% of the Oh sites [39]. However, for the proposed CNMEuF NPs, Mn3+ could preferentially occupy Td sites only and Eu3+, Co2+ as well as Ni2+ could occupy preferred Oh sites. According to the single-ion model, both Co2+ and Ni2+ are expected to occupy Oh sites in the totally inverse spinel structure [44,45], which was true for NPs with x≤ 0.06. However, for NPs containing x≥ 0.08, some of the Ni2+ could occupy the Td sites thereby transforming the
structures from inverse spinel configurations to normal ferrites. Meanwhile, the percentage occupancy of Fe3+ in the Td and Oh sites were reduced because of its substitution by Eu3+ having larger ionic radii wherein Fe3+ were expected occupy both Td and Oh sites.

sections.heading: 3.2. Surface morphology
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the FESEM micrograph of the as-prepared CNMEuF samples, which exhibited the assembly of small spherical NPs. The estimated NPs sizes (≈20 nm) for all samples were consistent with the one obtained from XRD analyses. The EDX spectra and elemental maps of spinel nanoferrites prepared with x=0.04 and 0.10 are illustrated in Fig. 4. It detected the correct stoichiometric composition in terms of elements Wt% including Co, Mn, Ni, Fe, Eu and O.
Fig. 5 displays the TEM images of synthesized CNMEuF NPs for x= 0.04 and 0.10, which disclosed cubic morphology with high aggregation tendency. The corresponding selective area electron diffraction (SAED) showed continuously isolated ring-like patterns that led to the formation a single phase of CNMEu spinel ferrites.

sections.heading: 3.3. FTIR spectra
sections.text:
Fig. 6 depicts the FTIR spectra of as- synthesized CNMEuF NPs, which divulged to distinct absorption peaks at 561.80 and 398.88 cm−1
assigned to the respective vibrational modes of MeO (metal-oxide) bond in the Td and Oh sites of spinel ferrites lattice [46,47]. The vibrational mode appeared at 561.80 cm−1 was further shifted towards the higher wavenumbers due to the substitution of Eu3+ ions. The observed blue shift was attributed to the shortening in the MeO bonds length and softening in the Td and Oh lattice sites [48]. Furthermore, the complete absence of extra peaks in the IR absorption spectrum clearly indicated the purity of the studied nanoferrites phases without any non-composite materials.

sections.heading: 3.4. Diffuse reflectance spectra
sections.text:
Fig. 7 depicts the percentage diffuse reflectance (DR%) of as-prepared CNMEuF NPs in the range of 200 nm–800 nm (corresponded to the photon energy range of 6.2 eV–1.55 eV) at room temperature. Such spectral data was used to determine the optoelectronic properties of the proposed Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 NPs for different Eu3+ doping contents. The reflectance spectra exhibited narrow bands with DR% in the range of 12–21% corresponding to the sweep region of UV–Visible spectrophotometer. Kubelka-Munk (K-M) theory was used to interpret the observed DR% spectral profile wherein the K-M function ∞F R( ) followed a direct proportionality to the materials absorption coefficient (α) via:
= − = =∞ ∞
∞
F R R R
εC S α( ) (1 ) 2 2.3032
(1)
where Cdenotes the analyte concentration, ∞R signifies the absolute remittance, S is twice the scattering coefficient and ε is the absorptivity of the material under study. The optical band gap energy (Eg) of CNMEuF NPs was evaluated using Tauc’s equation given by [49–51]:
= −αhυ A hυ E( ) ( )n g (2)
where is the h Planck constant, A is a constant, the index n denotes the type of electronic transition (direct or indirect allowed or forbidden transitions across the optical band gap) and υ is the frequency of incident photon. For a direct allowed transition n=2 and for an indirect allowed transition n=1/2.
Fig. 8 shows the Tauc plots ((αhυ)2 versus photon energy (hυ)) of the proposed Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 NPs for different values of x. These plots are generated by considering the direct allowed transitions across the optical band gap (for n=2). Average values of Eg were obtained from the intercept of linear portion of the plots to zero on the
energy axis. The achieved band gap for undoped spinel ferrite NPs was 1.47 eV. The doping by Eu3+ in the Co-Ni-Mn ferrites did not cause any significant change in the Eg values except at x= 0.08 and x= 0.10 in which the energy band gap was appreciably widened to 1.58 eV and 1.57 eV, respectively. Present observation is partially consistent with reported values of Eg in the literature for pristine, doped or mixed CoNi-Mn nanoferrites [52–58]. It was acknowledged that Eg values of doped Co-Ni-Mn nanoferrites could vary in the broad range of 1.46–3.85 eV. Similar observation was also made by Quinonez et al.
Fig. 6. FTIR spectra of studied CNMEuF NPs.
Fig. 7. Diffuse reflectance spectra of all nanoferrite compositions in the near UV and visible region.
[16] on impurities substituted Co-Ni-Mn nanoferrites.

sections.heading: 3.5. Magnetic properties
sections.text:
Figs. 9 and 10 displays magnetic hysteresis loops (M versus H curves) of all the studied CNMEuF NPs as a function of Eu3+ doping concentration recorded at RT and 10 K, respectively. Obviously, substitutions of Fe3+ in the lattice site by Eu3+ considerably influenced the magnetic behavior of the produced CNMEuF NPs. Following [59–61], Stoner–Wohlfarth (S–W) model was used to estimate the values of Ms. Ms, Mr and Hc for various compositions of spinel nanoferrites at 300 K
were correspondingly ranged from 9.6 to 25.5 emu/g, 0.5–3.1 emu/g and 11–245 Oe. Nevertheless, the observed values of Mr and Hc were almost insignificant. The RT magnetic behavior of various spinel ferrite NPs confirmed their superparamagnetic (SPM) character. The obtained values of Ms for various CNMEuF NPs at 10 K were ranged from 13.5 to 35.7 emu/g. The recorded hysteresis loops of almost all spinel nanoferrites at T= 10 K (Fig. 10b) showed clear coercivity, indicating the hard ferrimagnetic character. However, sample prepared with x= 0.10 showed very small coercivity at 10 K, indicating the soft ferrimagnetic nature. Furthermore, the hysteresis loops at 10 K (Fig. 10b) displayed a “wasp-waisted” or “kink” type behavior, which was not observed at RT.
This observation can be ascribed to varied mechanisms including magnetic coupling among the different magnetic phases such as soft Mn and hard Co and Ni having dissimilar coercivities and/or the applied external field assisted re-ordering of the magnetic spins at lower temperatures [62,63]. In addition, the re-orientation of spins (directional ordering) may be responsible for the variation of hysteresis loops that originate from the domain walls motion and the potential wells pinning [62,64], modifying the magnetic properties of synthesized nanoferrites.
Other factor such as the oxidation of soft magnetic layers due to atmospheric oxygen [62,65] could be accountable for such unusual magnetic response of CNMEuF NPs at low temperature. Briefly, complex mechanisms related to the grain boundaries combination and mixing of magnetic nanocomposites can contribute to contrasting magnetic properties [62,66]. In the present investigation, it is assumed that the “kink” behavior in the hysteresis loops of CNMEuF NPs could be due to the presence of assorted phases involving 30% of Co (hard), 50% of Ni (hard) and 20% of Mn (soft). Furthermore, the values of Ms, Mr and Hc were more enhanced when the temperature lower from 300 K to 10 K. Such increasing trend of magnetic parameters of the synthesized spinel nanoferrites at lower temperature can be attributed to the existence of the magnetic anisotropy and the scattering of particles in the anisotropic field directions [62,67,68]. Besides, the blocked magnetic moments aroused from weak thermal fluctuations inside the anisotropic potential barrier at lower temperature could be accountable for magnetic properties improvement [62,69]. Thus, the reduced thermal fluctuations at lower temperature could make the magnetic moments isotropic, which in turn enhance various magnetic parameters of the prepared CNMEuF NPs [62,70].
Fig. 11 illustrates the influence of Eu3+ substitution at different contents on the values of Ms, Mr and Hc of the studied Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 NPs. The undoped nanoferrites (Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2Fe2O4) NPs exhibited the highest values of Ms both at RT (25.5 emu/g) and at 10 K (35.7 emu/g). These values are lower compared to their bulk inverse counterpart [71], which was primarily assigned to the presence of tinier ferrite nanocrystallites in the sample. In fact, the dispersion of tinier NPs on the sample surface led to spins disordering through large surface to volume ratio [72,73], thereby lowered Ms. The occurrences of canted spins due to competitive antiferromagnetic interactions and resultant disordered distribution of cations on the sample surface could be responsible for reduced Ms value at 10 K [73,74]. At both measured temperatures, the values of Ms and Mr for the proposed nanoferrites compositions showed a declining trend with the increase in Eu3+ concentration, wherein Ms and Mr were lowest for the CNMEuF NPs prepared with x=0.10. Both Ms and Mr followed the same tendency with increasing Eu3+ doping contents [75].
Various studies suggested that the change in the magnetic traits of doped spinel nanoferrites can be decided by the presence of strains, grains sizes and its distribution, strength of the super-exchange interaction, alterations in magnetic moments (nB), thermal fluctuations mediated spin disordering, etc. [75,76]. The reduction in the Ms values with the shrinkage in the grains size has been acknowledged [75,76]. Herein, the observed lowering in the Ms and Mr with the increase in Eu3+ content agreed with the XRD outcomes that showed the shrinkages in the crystallites size thereby a reduction in the magnetizations. Furthermore, the replacement of Fe3+ having shorter ionic radius of 0.645 Å by Eu3+ with longer radius of 1.07 Å could create size mismatch assisted strains, leading to the alteration of electronic structures and spin disordering in the proposed nanoferrites [72]. Actually, the observed changes in the values of Ms are related to the fluctuations in the nBvalues. nB values were determined via [72]:
= × n Molecular Weight M
5585B s
Fig. 11(e) and (f) displays the Eu3+ contents dependent variation in the nB for the synthesized CNMEuF NPs obtained at RT and 10 K, respectively. The observed lowering in the nBvalues was attributed to the weak super-exchange coupling among different lattice sites due to the preferred occupancy of Eu3+ substituents. CNMEuF NPs prepared with x=0.00 revealed the maximum values of nB and Ms. Moreover, nB variation disclosed the similar lowering trend as that of Ms and Mr when Eu3+ contents were increased, implying deteriorating super-exchange interactions in NPs.
Fig. 11g and h show the variation of Hc as a function of Eu3+ concentrations. Nanoferrites prepared with x=0.10 showed maximum
Hc at both RT and 10 K. The coercivity of nanoferrites is usually decided by various factors such as the anisotropy in the magneto-crystallinity, morphologies (shapes, sizes, and distribution of grains) [72,77]. Fig. 11(i) and (j) present the Eu3+ contents dependent variation in SQR recorded at RT and 10 K. The values of SQR for nanoferrites with cubic and uniaxial anisotropy are generally known to be close to 0.83 and 0.50 [72]. If SQR is equal to or above 0.5, the NPs are known to exist in multiple magnetic domain (MMD) structures [72]. However, if SQR is below 0.5, the NPs are known to occur in single magnetic domain (SMD) structures [40]. In the proposed spinel nanoferrites, the SQR values at RT were ranged from 0.05 to 0.19 at RT, suggesting their uniaxially anisotropic SMD character. It is worth noting that at both temperatures the achieved CNMEuF NPs displayed SQR values below 0.5, signifying the presence of strong surface spin disordering [72]. At 10 K, CNMEuF NPs prepared with x= 0.00, 0.02 and 0.04 exhibited SQR values in the range of 0.61–0.68, indicating their uniaxially anisotropic SMD character. Samples synthesized with x≥ 0.06 displayed
SQR values under 0.48, suggesting their SMD character. Yet again, CNMEuF NPs composed with x= 0.10 disclosed the lowest SQR value at 10 K, which was attributed to the effects of surface spin disordering.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
For the first time, sonochemical reaction strategy was used to prepare spinel nanoferrites of the form Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 with 0.00≤ x≤ 0.10). Detailed structural, morphological and magnetic analyses of the proposed CNMEuF NPs confirmed the formation of spinel ferrite structure. The lattice parameter of CNMEuF NPs was shrunk with the raise in Eu3+ contents, wherein the nanocrystallite sizes were ranged from 12 to 21 nm. The distribution of cations was sensitive to the Eu3+ doping contents and their preferred occupancy in the B-site. The DR% analyses of the studied CNMEuF NPs revealed direct allowed optical transitions across the energy band gap of values in the range of 1.47 eV–1.58 eV. The room temperature hysteresis loops of
various Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4 compositions displayed SPM character. However, all the produced CNMEuF NPs except the one prepared with x=0.10 (displayed soft ferrimagnetic behavior) showed hard ferrimagnetic characteristic at 10 K. Irrespective of temperature variation, the values of magnetic parameters (Ms, Mr and nB) for the synthesized CNMEuF NPs were decreased with the increase in Eu3+ substitution contents. Such observations were attributed to the presence of local strains, dwindling of super-exchange couplings, grains size shrinkages (or crystallites size), surface spin disorder and reduced nB values.

metadata.abstractText: Nanoparticles (NPs) of composition Co0.3Ni0.5Mn0.2EuxFe2−xO4, where 0.00≤ x≤ 0.10 (hereafter called CNMEuF) were synthesized by sonochemical approach using UZ SONOPULS HD 2070 ultrasonic homogenizer (frequency of 20 kHz and power of 70W). As-synthesized samples were characterized thoroughly to determine the effects of europium ions (Eu) substitution on their structure, morphology and magnetic traits. Structural analyses of the synthesized NPs confirmed their high purity and crystalline cubic phases. Percent diffuse reflectance (%DR) data and Kubelka-Munk theory were exploited to evaluate the optical band gap energies of the studied CNMEuF NPs. Values of optical band gap energies obtained from the Tauc plots were observed in the range of 1.47–1.58 eV. The hysteresis loops (at room temperature and 10 K) of synthesized NPs were analyzed to determine their magnetic properties. These NPs disclosed superparamagnetic and hard ferrimagnetic character at room temperature and 10 K, respectively. With exception, the sample with x= 0.10 revealed soft ferrimagnetic behavior at 10 K. Eu doping was shown to have significant influence on the structure and magnetic attributes of the proposed CNMEuF NPs. Values of various magnetic parameters of proposed compositions were reduced with the increase in Eu dopant contents.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
